awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Deep Ancestry of the Indigenous People of North America
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the investigators will utilize the latest advances in DNA sequencing technology and population genetics to elucidate the evolutionary history of Native Americans, on both a regional and continental level, and establish genetic reference panels specific to indigenous Nations. The project will expand collaborative efforts between researchers with an interest in studying important events in Native American history and will continue research collaborations with tribal community members. Results will be shared with participants from seven Native American Nations throughout North America and also made available via a dedicated analysis server. The project also will enhance the successful Summer internship for INdigenous peoples in Genomics (SING) workshop by creating an alumni conference to take place in the summer of 2021. This conference will include a public event with a focus on presentations of social and ethical aspects of genomics research with indigenous communities, as well as a workshop to tackle relevant issues, such as the development of mutually beneficial agreements between researchers and communities.

The comprehensive study design of this project will utilize genome-level data from participating indigenous communities throughout North America, which will advance our understanding of ancient migrations and adaptations to local environments, ranging from the Subarctic to the Sonoran Desert. Comparative analyses between tribes will provide a unique perspective on the local evolutionary history of the Americas, with an additional emphasis on the effects of European colonization, which resulted in devasting population declines from a variety of factors, including disease and warfare. These findings will be contextualized in a broader demographic framework to provide a richer characterization of the evolution of these adaptations, while elucidating nuanced demographic histories complicated by disease and colonization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding human demographic and adaptive history from genetic data requires the detection and distillation of subtle patterns along with the concerted effort of teams of anthropologists, archaeologists, biologists, computer scientists, and statisticians in collaboration with Indigenous communities. In this project, we use patterns of genetic data from contemporary and ancient populations of the Americas to elucidate past migration events, learn about population structure, estimate the effect of European colonization on Indigenous genome variation, and detect and quantify local adaptation while correlating such events with environmental pressures. In particular, we uncovered migration paths of Indigenous peoples within South America, found greater Denisovan than Neanderthal ancestry in some ancient individuals within South America, detected a significant Austalasian signal within ancient individuals from Panama, and characterized the genetic structure, demographic history, and local adaptation of several Indigenous communities within North America.


In addition, we pursued a number of other methodological development initiatives related to learning about population adaptation. These include development of statistical and machine learning approaches for uncovering patterns of different natural selection processes within genomes. Specifically, these approaches evaluate skews in distributions in the frequencies of genome sequences (software SS-X12, LASSI, and saltiLASSI), extract robust features from images of such sequences for use in downstream modeling (software alpha-DAWG, T-REx, and TrIdent), and better model the correlated structure of the genome (software SURFDAWave and SISSSCO).


Results from these and other related studies have been widely disseminated to the scientific community through publication of 29 peer-reviewed scientific journal articles, 19 open-source software products, seven invited seminar talks at research institutions, and seven oral and seven poster presentations at national and international meetings. Moreover, the project trained seven Ph.D. students and three postdoctoral researchers, with postdoctoral researchers securing tenure-track faculty positions at R1 and flagship universities and Ph.D. students securing scientist positions at biotechnology companies, a faculty position at a R1 institution, and as postdoctoral researchers at R1 universities. Finally, major broader impact initiatives were supported by this project, including guest lectures at Florida Atlantic University High School and the I-DeepLearn summer workshop for high school girls on the intersection of artificial intelligence and population genomics, a seminar as part of the Florida Atlantic University Virtual Research in Action series to connect with a broad international public audience on how genetic information can be used to learn about recent and ancestral population structure and history, and an outreach discussion to high school National Merit Finalists on how computer science techniques in conjuction with genetic information from modern and ancient individuals can be used to understand past history.
